Text: Cryptoassets provide strong innovation potential, helping the UK stay competitive in fintech. However, MPs raise concerns about market volatility, crypto scams, and lack of regulation that may leave consumers unprotected. Parliament insists regulation must balance innovation with safety to build trust. Stablecoins could reduce transaction costs and unlock new payment models but risk destabilising markets if not supported by proper reserve assets. The FCA must closely supervise crypto firms to ensure transparency, cyber resilience, and AML compliance.

Members highlight that many young people are attracted into crypto investing without understanding volatility. Parliament stresses rapid policy action to prevent fraud, misleading promotions, and unregulated exchanges harming UK citizens. MPs request improved education and stronger risk disclosures.

MPs debate the need to classify cryptoassets within UK tax rules. Uncertainty around staking rewards, wallet-based capital gains, and token distributions may lead to tax evasion or unintentional breaches. Proper guidance will ensure fairness and help mainstream adoption.

The UK seeks to become a global hub for blockchain innovation. Parliament acknowledges huge growth opportunities but stresses that risks such as cybercrime and market manipulation must be managed carefully with clear regulation.

Marketing content often hides risk and exaggerates profit potential. MPs call for the FCA to enforce transparent messaging that ensures consumers are aware they may lose all invested funds. Strengthened oversight is needed.

Exchange collapses have shown how failures can spread panic across markets. Parliament urges Treasury and FCA to implement strict operational resilience rules for crypto payment systems and custodians.

Crypto is frequently used for money laundering and ransomware payments. Parliament proposes advanced blockchain analytics, stronger law enforcement cooperation, and higher penalties for firms enabling illegal finance.

Scams, phishing links, and fraud continue targeting inexperienced retail investors. MPs recommend better public awareness campaigns and an early-warning framework for harmful platforms before customers are affected.
Members raise concerns that decentralised finance may worsen financial instability if poorly managed liquidity and code failures occur. Accountability mechanisms must ensure investor rights.

Blockchain can support digital ID, smart contracts, and supply chain tracking. UK should introduce sandbox testing and responsible innovation grants while maintaining consumer-first principles in regulation.

MPs state that crypto lending platforms operate with unclear governance and no capital protection, exposing consumers to severe financial losses if a firm collapses. Parliament urges Treasury to set minimum reserve requirements, segregation of client assets, and mandatory external audits. A stronger framework would ensure accountability and transparency. Blockchain innovation must not outpace risk controls.

Growing concerns arise about leveraged crypto trading encouraging risky debt among young people. Parliament stresses affordability checks, suitability assessments, and clearer labelling of high-risk speculation. Education initiatives are vital to improve awareness of liquidation risks and irreversible blockchain transactions.

MPs warn that ransomware growth is tightly linked to untraceable crypto payment channels. Parliament proposes increased intelligence sharing with international regulators and deployment of blockchain forensics to detect hacked fund flows. National security concerns demand stronger monitoring of crypto mixing services.

The UK should embrace tokenisation to drive efficiency in property and supply chain markets. Parliament encourages innovation hubs but insists that developers launching high-risk tokens remain accountable to regulators for consumer safety and transparent disclosures.

Insider trading occurs when privileged actors exploit new token listings before the public. MPs call for market surveillance tools and restrictions on trading by insiders prior to announcements, ensuring fairness similar to regulated securities markets.

Parliament urges that clearer governance and accountability apply to crypto custodians and wallet providers. Recent failures show users can lose funds without redress. Calls made for FCA to accelerate approval processes while enforcing resilience standards to avoid systemic damage.

Members emphasise that encrypted blockchain services can hide stolen money. Parliament asks for strict regulation of crypto mixers and mandatory reporting of suspicious wallet patterns. Coordination between police and crypto analytics firms is needed.

Parliament emphasises digital literacy education because investors struggle to identify phishing attacks, including fake wallet recovery links. MPs demand major technology platforms remove harmful advertisements and support secure identity tools.

MPs discuss integrating stablecoins into the UK retail payment ecosystem. Mandatory liquidity coverage, redemption guarantees, and fraud safeguards are needed before widespread adoption to prevent economic shocks.

Debate notes that regulatory sandboxes accelerate fintech growth, but Parliament insists firms in testing must not exploit consumers. Stronger transparency rules for token issuers help avoid speculative crashes and maintain public trust in digital assets.
